mn26:1.1.comm: This discourse is known in Pali manuscripts and commentaries either as “The Noble Quest” or “The Pile of Snares”, whereas the Chinese parallel at MA 204 is titled “The Discourse at Rāma’s Hermitage”. It is one of several discourses in the Majjhima that include a partial account of Siddhattha’s practice before awakening, an account that became one of the key events in the Buddha’s biography. This particular version focuses on his experience with Brahmanical teachers, while MN 36, MN 85, and MN 100 include a long passage detailing his Jain-like fervent austerities.

mn26:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn26:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn26:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn26:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

mn26:2.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn26:2.2.eng: Then several mendicants went up to Venerable Ānanda and said to him,

mn26:2.3.pli: “cirassutā no, āvuso ānanda, bhagavato sammukhā dhammī kathā.
mn26:2.3.eng: “Reverend, it’s been a long time since we’ve heard a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.
mn26:2.3.comm: Why was the Buddha reluctant to teach? This is puzzling because where we find this trope elsewhere there is a clear reason: at AN 7.52:1.3 the Buddha was making one of his rare visits to Campā, while at SN 22.81:3.5 he had left the squabbling Sangha for the seclusion of the forest. Here, in the central teaching location of Sāvatthī, there is no such reason. Rather, the events are best understood as narrative foreshadowing. His reluctance requires an intervention by others, and when the teaching finally takes place it is not in a Buddhist monastery but on Brahmanical grounds. The story goes on to tell how, after his awakening, he was reluctant to teach until the intervention of Brahmā (MN 26:19.1). This narrative mirroring creates a hidden link (sandhi) that frames the awakening in a Brahmanical context. The very obscurity of the connection is the point, for “the gods love hidden things”. The theme of reluctance is extended further to the reluctance of the five mendicants to receive the Buddha. It draws on the precedent of Yājñavalkya’s reluctance to teach Janaka (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.1).

mn26:2.4.pli: Sādhu mayaṃ, āvuso ānanda, labheyyāma bhagavato sammukhā dhammiṃ kathaṃ savanāyā”ti.
mn26:2.4.eng: It would be good if we got to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”

mn26:2.5.pli: “Tena hāyasmanto yena rammakassa brāhmaṇassa assamo tenupasaṅkamatha;
mn26:2.5.eng: “Well then, reverends, go to the brahmin Rammaka’s hermitage.
mn26:2.5.comm: Rammaka appears only here, and the commentary offers no information. His name presumably signifies that he was a follower of the teacher Rāma who appears below. This complements AN 3.126:3.3, where the Buddha stays in the hermitage of Bharaṇḍu the Kālāma, who was apparently a student of Āḷāra Kālāma.

mn26:2.6.pli: appeva nāma labheyyātha bhagavato sammukhā dhammiṃ kathaṃ savanāyā”ti.
mn26:2.6.eng: Hopefully you’ll get to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”

mn26:2.7.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato ānandassa paccassosuṃ.

mn26:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
mn26:3.1.eng: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, the Buddha addressed Ānanda,
mn26:3.1.comm: The narrative sequence from the Buddha returning from alms round to coming out from his bath is also found at AN 6.43:1.3. There, there is a clear justification for the story, as the discourse concerns a royal elephant parade seen after bathing. Here, once more, the purpose is implicit: a brahmanical student must bathe before any ritual.

mn26:3.2.eng: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery for the day’s meditation.”
mn26:3.2.comm: After the Jetavana, this was the best-known monastery in Sāvatthī. It was offered by the lady Visākhā, known as Migāra’s mother.

mn26:3.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

mn26:3.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ yena pubbārāmo migāramātupāsādo tenupasaṅkami divāvihārāya.
mn26:3.4.eng: So the Buddha went with Ānanda to the Eastern Monastery for the day’s meditation.

mn26:3.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
mn26:3.5.eng: In the late afternoon the Buddha came out of retreat and addressed Ānanda,

mn26:3.6.eng: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the eastern gate to bathe.”

mn26:3.7.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

mn26:3.8.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ yena pubbakoṭṭhako tenupasaṅkami gattāni parisiñcituṃ.
mn26:3.8.eng: So the Buddha went with Ānanda to the eastern gate to bathe.

mn26:3.9.pli: Pubbakoṭṭhake gattāni parisiñcitvā paccuttaritvā ekacīvaro aṭṭhāsi gattāni pubbāpayamāno.
mn26:3.9.eng: When he had bathed and emerged from the water he stood in one robe drying his limbs.

mn26:3.10.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn26:3.10.eng: Then Ānanda said to the Buddha,

mn26:3.11.eng: “Sir, the hermitage of the brahmin Rammaka is nearby.

mn26:3.14.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā yena rammakassa brāhmaṇassa assamo tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
mn26:3.14.eng: Please visit it out of sympathy.”

mn26:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena rammakassa brāhmaṇassa assamo tenupasaṅkami.
mn26:4.1.eng: He went to the brahmin Rammaka’s hermitage.

mn26:4.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū rammakassa brāhmaṇassa assame dhammiyā kathāya sannisinnā honti.
mn26:4.2.eng: Now at that time several mendicants were sitting together in the hermitage talking about the teaching.
mn26:4.2.comm: Here (and at MN 92:4.1) a “hermitage” (assama, “ashram”) is a sizable building suitable for gatherings, whereas at SN 11.9:1.4 it is a gated compound with leaf huts. It is normally used for Brahmanical places.

mn26:4.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bahidvārakoṭṭhake aṭṭhāsi kathāpariyosānaṃ āgamayamāno.
mn26:4.3.eng: The Buddha stood outside the door waiting for the talk to end.

mn26:4.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā kathāpariyosānaṃ viditvā ukkāsitvā aggaḷaṃ ākoṭesi.
mn26:4.4.eng: When he knew the talk had ended he cleared his throat and knocked on the door-panel.

mn26:4.5.pli: Vivariṃsu kho te bhikkhū bhagavato dvāraṃ.
mn26:4.5.eng: The mendicants opened the door for the Buddha,

mn26:4.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rammakassa brāhmaṇassa assamaṃ pavisitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
mn26:4.6.eng: and he entered the hermitage, where he sat on the seat spread out

mn26:4.8.pli: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā? Kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
mn26:4.8.eng: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”

mn26:4.9.pli: “Bhagavantameva kho no, bhante, ārabbha dhammī kathā vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
mn26:4.9.eng: “Sir, our unfinished discussion on the teaching was about the Buddha himself when the Buddha arrived.”

mn26:4.11.pli: Etaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tumhākaṃ patirūpaṃ kulaputtānaṃ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitānaṃ yaṃ tumhe dhammiyā kathāya sannisīdeyyātha.
mn26:4.11.eng: It’s appropriate for gentlemen like you, who have gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, to sit together and talk about the teaching.

mn26:4.12.eng: When you’re sitting together you should do one of two things:

mn26:4.13.pli: dhammī vā kathā, ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo.
mn26:4.13.eng: discuss the teachings or keep noble silence.
mn26:4.13.comm: “Noble silence” is narrowly defined as the second absorption (SN 21.1).

mn26:5.1.eng: Mendicants, there are these two quests:
mn26:5.1.comm: The Buddha picks up from the fact that the mendicants were talking about him, but continues in a depersonalized manner. | The substance of this passage is taught more briefly at AN 4.255.

mn26:5.2.pli: ariyā ca pariyesanā, anariyā ca pariyesanā.
mn26:5.2.eng: the noble quest and the ignoble quest.
mn26:5.2.comm: These opposing quests (or “searches”, pariyesanā) respond to Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.22, which we have already noted as a source for the phrase so attā so loko (MN 22:15.10). It says that the wise ones of old, renouncing the search for sons, for wealth, and for the heavenly worlds, lived the mendicant’s life (putraiṣaṇāyāśca vittaiṣaṇāyāśca lokaiṣaṇāyāśca vyutthāyātha bhikśācaryaṁ caranti). The inner self sought by the brahmins is described as unborn, made of consciousness, undecaying, unattached, and unaffected by karma; knowing it one becomes a sage. See too BU 3.5.1.

mn26:5.3.eng: And what is the ignoble quest?

mn26:5.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco attanā jātidhammo samāno jātidhammaṃyeva pariyesati, attanā jarādhammo samāno jarādhammaṃyeva pariyesati, attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhidhammaṃyeva pariyesati, attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇadhammaṃyeva pariyesati, attanā sokadhammo samāno sokadhammaṃyeva pariyesati, attanā saṅkilesadhammo samāno saṅkilesadhammaṃyeva pariyesati.
mn26:5.4.eng: It’s when someone who is themselves liable to be reborn seeks what is also liable to be reborn. Themselves liable to grow old, fall sick, die, sorrow, and become corrupted, they seek what is also liable to these things.

mn26:6.1.eng: And what should be described as liable to be reborn?
mn26:6.1.comm: The Pali includes “gold and money” among those things subject to birth, old age, and defilement. The Chinese parallel MA 204 (T i 776a7; cf. T 765 at T xvii 679b23) does not mention “birth” but says money and jewelry are subject to old age, defilement, etc. Elsewhere in the suttas, rebirth, old age, and defilement are qualities of sentient beings, not inanimate objects, so this might be a textual corruption. Nonetheless, the commentary offers explanations for why gold and money are included under these specific categories and not the rest, and this, together with the Chinese text, shows that if it is a corruption it is an old one. I give the commentarial explanations.

mn26:6.2.pli: Puttabhariyaṃ, bhikkhave, jātidhammaṃ, dāsidāsaṃ jātidhammaṃ, ajeḷakaṃ jātidhammaṃ, kukkuṭasūkaraṃ jātidhammaṃ, hatthigavāssavaḷavaṃ jātidhammaṃ, jātarūparajataṃ jātidhammaṃ.
mn26:6.2.eng: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, elephants and cattle, and gold and currency are liable to be reborn.
mn26:6.2.comm: Gold and money are subject to “birth” because they are produced by heat (utusamuṭṭhāna). | The word for “gold” here, one of several in Pali, is jātarūpa, literally “born form”, i.e. that which is naturally beautiful. In Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.4.25, a newborn infant is to be fed mixed curd, honey, and ghee with a piece of jātarūpa, thus placing “golden” Vedic speech in him. This rare early instance of jātarūpa shows that it had a felt connection with the idea of birth. Perhaps this connection prompted its inclusion here. From that, “money” (rajata) was brought in as the two form a stock phrase, and they were then applied elsewhere in the list.

mn26:6.3.eng: These attachments are liable to be reborn.

mn26:6.4.pli: Etthāyaṃ gathito mucchito ajjhāpanno attanā jātidhammo samāno jātidhammaṃyeva pariyesati.
mn26:6.4.eng: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and attached to such things, themselves liable to being reborn, seeks what is also liable to be reborn.

mn26:7.1.eng: And what should be described as liable to grow old?

mn26:7.2.pli: Puttabhariyaṃ, bhikkhave, jarādhammaṃ, dāsidāsaṃ jarādhammaṃ, ajeḷakaṃ jarādhammaṃ, kukkuṭasūkaraṃ jarādhammaṃ, hatthigavāssavaḷavaṃ jarādhammaṃ, jātarūparajataṃ jarādhammaṃ.
mn26:7.2.eng: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, elephants and cattle, and gold and currency are liable to grow old.
mn26:7.2.comm: Gold and money grow old due to rust or grime.

mn26:7.3.eng: These attachments are liable to grow old.

mn26:7.4.pli: Etthāyaṃ gathito mucchito ajjhāpanno attanā jarādhammo samāno jarādhammaṃyeva pariyesati.
mn26:7.4.eng: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and attached to such things, themselves liable to grow old, seeks what is also liable to grow old.

mn26:8.1.eng: And what should be described as liable to fall sick?

mn26:8.2.pli: Puttabhariyaṃ, bhikkhave, byādhidhammaṃ, dāsidāsaṃ byādhidhammaṃ, ajeḷakaṃ byādhidhammaṃ, kukkuṭasūkaraṃ byādhidhammaṃ, hatthigavāssavaḷavaṃ byādhidhammaṃ.
mn26:8.2.eng: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and elephants and cattle are liable to fall sick.

mn26:8.3.eng: These attachments are liable to fall sick.

mn26:8.4.pli: Etthāyaṃ gathito mucchito ajjhāpanno attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhidhammaṃyeva pariyesati.
mn26:8.4.eng: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and attached to such things, themselves liable to falling sick, seeks what is also liable to fall sick.

mn26:9.1.eng: And what should be described as liable to die?

mn26:9.2.pli: Puttabhariyaṃ, bhikkhave, maraṇadhammaṃ, dāsidāsaṃ maraṇadhammaṃ, ajeḷakaṃ maraṇadhammaṃ, kukkuṭasūkaraṃ maraṇadhammaṃ, hatthigavāssavaḷavaṃ maraṇadhammaṃ.
mn26:9.2.eng: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and elephants and cattle are liable to die.

mn26:9.3.eng: These attachments are liable to die.

mn26:9.4.pli: Etthāyaṃ gathito mucchito ajjhāpanno attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇadhammaṃyeva pariyesati.
mn26:9.4.eng: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and attached to such things, themselves liable to die, seeks what is also liable to die.

mn26:10.1.eng: And what should be described as liable to sorrow?

mn26:10.2.pli: Puttabhariyaṃ, bhikkhave, sokadhammaṃ, dāsidāsaṃ sokadhammaṃ, ajeḷakaṃ sokadhammaṃ, kukkuṭasūkaraṃ sokadhammaṃ, hatthigavāssavaḷavaṃ sokadhammaṃ.
mn26:10.2.eng: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and elephants and cattle are liable to sorrow.

mn26:10.3.eng: These attachments are liable to sorrow.

mn26:10.4.pli: Etthāyaṃ gathito mucchito ajjhāpanno attanā sokadhammo samāno sokadhammaṃyeva pariyesati.
mn26:10.4.eng: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and attached to such things, themselves liable to sorrow, seeks what is also liable to sorrow.

mn26:11.1.eng: And what should be described as liable to corruption?

mn26:11.2.pli: Puttabhariyaṃ, bhikkhave, saṅkilesadhammaṃ, dāsidāsaṃ saṅkilesadhammaṃ, ajeḷakaṃ saṅkilesadhammaṃ, kukkuṭasūkaraṃ saṅkilesadhammaṃ, hatthigavāssavaḷavaṃ saṅkilesadhammaṃ, jātarūparajataṃ saṅkilesadhammaṃ.
mn26:11.2.eng: Partners and children, male and female bondservants, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, elephants and cattle, and gold and currency are liable to corruption.
mn26:11.2.comm: Gold and money are liable to corruption by iron, etc.

mn26:11.3.eng: These attachments are liable to corruption.

mn26:11.4.pli: Etthāyaṃ gathito mucchito ajjhāpanno attanā saṅkilesadhammo samāno saṅkilesadhammaṃyeva pariyesati.
mn26:11.4.eng: Someone who is tied, infatuated, and attached to such things, themselves liable to corruption, seeks what is also liable to corruption.

mn26:12.1.eng: And what is the noble quest?

mn26:12.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco attanā jātidhammo samāno jātidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajātaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati, attanā jarādhammo samāno jarādhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajaraṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati, attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā abyādhiṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati, attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā amataṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati, attanā sokadhammo samāno sokadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā asokaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati, attanā saṅkilesadhammo samāno saṅkilesadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā asaṅkiliṭṭhaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati.
mn26:12.2.eng: It’s when someone who is themselves liable to be reborn, understanding the drawbacks in being liable to be reborn, seeks that which is free of rebirth, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment. Themselves liable to grow old, fall sick, die, sorrow, and become corrupted, understanding the drawbacks in these things, they seek that which is free of old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and corruption, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment.
mn26:12.2.comm: As pointed out by K.R. Norman in his Mistaken Ideas About Nibbāna (1994), the epithets ajātaṁ (etc.) don’t mean that Nibbāna is “unborn”, but rather that in Nibbāna there is no rebirth. Likewise, amata does not mean “immortal” or “deathless” but “freedom from death”.

mn26:13.1.pli: Ahampi sudaṃ, bhikkhave, pubbeva sambodhā anabhisambuddho bodhisattova samāno attanā jātidhammo samāno jātidhammaṃyeva pariyesāmi, attanā jarādhammo samāno jarādhammaṃyeva pariyesāmi, attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhidhammaṃyeva pariyesāmi, attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇadhammaṃyeva pariyesāmi, attanā sokadhammo samāno sokadhammaṃyeva pariyesāmi, attanā saṅkilesadhammo samāno saṅkilesadhammaṃyeva pariyesāmi.
mn26:13.1.eng: Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too, being liable to be reborn, sought what is also liable to be reborn. Myself liable to grow old, fall sick, die, sorrow, and become corrupted, I sought what is also liable to these things.

mn26:13.3.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho ahaṃ attanā jātidhammo samāno jātidhammaṃyeva pariyesāmi, attanā jarādhammo samāno …pe… byādhidhammo samāno … maraṇadhammo samāno … sokadhammo samāno … attanā saṅkilesadhammo samāno saṅkilesadhammaṃyeva pariyesāmi?
mn26:13.3.eng: ‘Why do I, being liable to be reborn, grow old, fall sick, sorrow, die, and become corrupted, seek things that have the same nature?

mn26:13.4.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ attanā jātidhammo samāno jātidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajātaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyeseyyaṃ, attanā jarādhammo samāno jarādhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajaraṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyeseyyaṃ, attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā abyādhiṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyeseyyaṃ, attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā amataṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyeseyyaṃ, attanā sokadhammo samāno sokadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā asokaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyeseyyaṃ, attanā saṅkilesadhammo samāno saṅkilesadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā asaṅkiliṭṭhaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyeseyyan’ti.
mn26:13.4.eng: Why don’t I seek that which is free of rebirth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and corruption, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment?’

mn26:14.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, aparena samayena daharova samāno susukāḷakeso, bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā akāmakānaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ assumukhānaṃ rudantānaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajiṃ.
mn26:14.1.eng: Some time later, while still with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life—though my mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces—I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
mn26:14.1.comm: This contrasts with the legend that he slipped away in the dead of night.

mn26:15.1.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno kiṅkusalagavesī anuttaraṃ santivarapadaṃ pariyesamāno yena āḷāro kālāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃ. upasaṅkamitvā āḷāraṃ kālāmaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn26:15.1.eng: Once I had gone forth I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
mn26:15.1.comm: “To discover what is skillful” (kiṅkusalagavesī) might also be translated, “seeking to answer the question, ‘what is good?’.” At this point he did not know the path so he sought an answer from the best teachers of his day. | At MN 102:25.1, the “supreme state of sublime peace” (santivarapada) is said to be “liberation without grasping” (anupādāvimokkha). | Āḷāra Kālāma was a senior teacher in the contemplative and renunciate tradition of the Upaniṣads. His meditative prowess is praised by his student Pukkusa the Mallian at DN 16:4.26.1, but is seen to be inferior to the Buddha’s. At AN 3.126:6.2 an apparent former student of Āḷāra advocates that teachers who teach full understanding of different things are nonetheless leading to the same goal. Thus, in line with Upaniṣadic philosophy, Āḷāra saw the apparent diversity of phenomena as partial manifestations of the immanent cosmic divinity. Āḷāra is usually understood to be named after his people, the Kālāmas. But it is possible we should accept the variant Kālāpa, indicating that he follows the Black Yajurveda.

mn26:15.2.pli: ‘icchāmahaṃ, āvuso kālāma, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye brahmacariyaṃ caritun’ti.
mn26:15.2.eng: ‘Reverend Kālāma, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’
mn26:15.2.comm: Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.4.1 sets out the initiation (upanayana) into “spiritual life” (brahmacarya) according to Yājñavalkya. The student says, “I have come for brahmacarya” or “Let me be a brahmacāri”. The teacher responds by asking, “What is your name” (ko nāmāsīti). The same phrase is used in the Buddhist ordination procedure (kiṁnāmosi, Kd 1:76.1.15). But whereas in Buddhism this is merely a personal identification, for the brahmins this naming signifies a mystical identity with the creator Prajāpati, who is ka.

mn26:15.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, āḷāro kālāmo maṃ etadavoca:

mn26:15.4.comm: Āḷāra Kālāma calls his student āyasmā (Sanskrit āyuṣmant), an honorific that in the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa is reserved for the god Agni (13.8.4.8–9). By this he indicates the student’s divine status. | Compare with the first phrase used by the Buddha to ordain his students, “Come, mendicant” (ehi bhikkhu, Kd 1:6.32.3).

mn26:15.5.pli: tādiso ayaṃ dhammo yattha viññū puriso nacirasseva sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
mn26:15.5.eng: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’
mn26:15.5.comm: “Their own tradition” (sakaṁ ācariyakaṁ), literally “what belongs to their own teacher” (ācariya, Sanskrit ācarya). In the Brahmanical initiation, having accepted the student, the brahmin takes him by the hand and says, “Agni is your teacher, I am your teacher” (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.4.2). This claims both the universal authority of the divine lineage as well as the personal lineage of that teacher. | “Their own insight” (sayaṁ abhiññā); Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa repeatedly emphasizes that the benefits of initiation are for “one who knows this” (ya evaṁ veda, 11.5.4.2, etc.).

mn26:15.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, nacirasseva khippameva taṃ dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇiṃ.
mn26:15.6.comm: The text does not specify the scripture that he learned, but it must have been Brahmanical, for they were the only scriptures known. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.4.13 instructs the new student to first learn the Sāvitrī, specifying the version in Gāyatrī metre (see also Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.14). The Buddha refers to this as the foremost verse (MN 92:26.2), and he even specifies the Gāyatrī version (Snp 3.4:7.3). Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.7 goes on to encourage the student in daily recitation of the four Vedas and ancillary literature.

mn26:15.7.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, tāvatakeneva oṭṭhapahatamattena lapitalāpanamattena ñāṇavādañca vadāmi theravādañca, ‘jānāmi passāmī’ti ca paṭijānāmi ahañceva aññe ca.
mn26:15.7.eng: As far as lip-recital and verbal repetition went, I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.
mn26:15.7.comm: “I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine” (ñāṇavādañca vadāmi theravādañca). Taken together, the sense is that his personal understanding agreed with tradition. A less literal translation might be, “I spoke with knowledge and authority.” | For ñāṇavāda, compare such passages as Snp 4.3:2.4, “as you know, so you speak” (yathā hi jāneyya tathā vadeyya). In the Brāhmaṇas and Upaniṣads, knowledge refers to the hidden connections between the Vedas and the world which reveal the divinity immanent in all things. | Thera (Sanskrit sthavira) has the senses “steady, strong” (so commentary’s thirabhāva) as well as “elder”, for which see Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa 26.2.5, where Jātūkarṇya, a teacher of old, is called sthavira. I take it to mean the “lasting doctrine of the ancients”. This is the oldest use of the word theravāda, long before it was applied to a Buddhist school.

mn26:15.9.pli: ‘na kho āḷāro kālāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ kevalaṃ saddhāmattakena sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedeti;
mn26:15.9.eng: ‘It is not solely by mere faith that Āḷāra Kālāma declares: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”
mn26:15.9.comm: “Faith” (or “trust”, saddhā, Sanskrit śraddhā) was regarded as a quality of the “heart” through which one gained remuneration in the form of fees for priestly services (Rig Veda 10.151.4, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.9.21). It is like the “trust” that one would place in a bank: an investment is made in expectation of a reward. | For the syntax here, compare with kevalaṁ vassagaṇanamattena at AN 7.43:5.6.

mn26:15.10.pli: addhā āḷāro kālāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ viharatī’ti.
mn26:15.10.eng: Surely he meditates knowing and seeing this teaching.’

mn26:15.11.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, yena āḷāro kālāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā āḷāraṃ kālāmaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn26:15.11.eng: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,

mn26:15.12.pli: ‘kittāvatā no, āvuso kālāma, imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesī’ti?
mn26:15.12.eng: ‘Reverend Kālāma, to what extent do you say you’ve realized this teaching with your own insight?’

mn26:15.13.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, āḷāro kālāmo ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ pavedesi.
mn26:15.13.eng: When I said this, he declared the dimension of nothingness.
mn26:15.13.comm: This is said to be the best of the four perceptions at (AN 10.29:18.1). Buddhist texts portray this as a favorite meditation among brahmin contemplatives (eg. Snp 5.15:2.1, Snp 5.7:2.1). While one might expect that the brahmins would identify their goal in a positive sense, this is not always the case. A text of the Black Yajurveda, Kaṭha Upaniṣad 1.3.11, says that beyond the great Soul, beyond the unmanifest, beyond the Person, is nothing: and that is the ultimate goal (puruśān na paraṃ kiṃcit). See too Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.12.1, which illustrate how divinity is too subtle for normal perception. The teacher, breaking the kernel of a seed, asked the student, ““What do you see there?’ ‘Nothing’” (kimatra paśyasīti, na kiṁcana). Compare the description of this state at Snp 5.15:2.4, “one sees nothing at all” (natthi kiñcīti passato). This is also similar to the teaching of Uddaka (MN 26:16.1).

mn26:15.15.pli: ‘na kho āḷārasseva kālāmassa atthi saddhā, mayhampatthi saddhā;
mn26:15.15.eng: ‘It’s not just Āḷāra Kālāma who has faith,
mn26:15.15.comm: The Buddha called these the five “faculties” (SN 48.10) or “powers” (AN 5.14). All except “immersion” (samādhi) are frequently mentioned in pre-Buddhist texts, but not as a set of five.

mn26:15.16.pli: na kho āḷārasseva kālāmassa atthi vīriyaṃ, mayhampatthi vīriyaṃ;

mn26:15.17.pli: na kho āḷārasseva kālāmassa atthi sati, mayhampatthi sati;

mn26:15.18.pli: na kho āḷārasseva kālāmassa atthi samādhi, mayhampatthi samādhi;
mn26:15.18.comm: The mention of “immersion” implies the prior development of the four absorptions. The formless attainments are “progressive meditations” (AN 9.32) achieved by a process of “progressive cessation” (AN 9.31). Though formless, they are dependent on form (SN 14.11:3.3).

mn26:15.19.pli: na kho āḷārasseva kālāmassa atthi paññā, mayhampatthi paññā.
mn26:15.19.eng: and wisdom; I too have these things.

mn26:15.20.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yaṃ dhammaṃ āḷāro kālāmo sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedeti, tassa dhammassa sacchikiriyāya padaheyyan’ti.
mn26:15.20.eng: Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Āḷāra Kālāma says he has realized with his own insight?’

mn26:15.21.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, nacirasseva khippameva taṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
mn26:15.21.eng: I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.
mn26:15.21.comm: This phrasing echoes part of the description of arahantship (MN 85:51.12).

mn26:15.22.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, yena āḷāro kālāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā āḷāraṃ kālāmaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn26:15.22.eng: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,

mn26:15.23.pli: ‘Ettāvatā no, āvuso kālāma, imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesī’ti?
mn26:15.23.eng: ‘Reverend Kālāma, is it up to this point that you realized this teaching with your own insight, and declare having achieved it?’
mn26:15.23.comm: Having achieved that state, Āḷāra Kālāma “declares” (pavedeti) it as the teacher, while the Bodhisatta “dwells” in it (viharati).

mn26:15.24.pli: ‘Ettāvatā kho ahaṃ, āvuso, imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedemī’ti.

mn26:15.25.pli: ‘Ahampi kho, āvuso, ettāvatā imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmī’ti.
mn26:15.25.eng: ‘I too, reverend, have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’

mn26:15.26.eng: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate

mn26:15.27.pli: ye mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ tādisaṃ sabrahmacāriṃ passāma.
mn26:15.27.eng: to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!

mn26:15.28.pli: Iti yāhaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedemi taṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharasi.
mn26:15.28.eng: So the teaching that I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it, you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it.

mn26:15.29.pli: Yaṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharasi tamahaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedemi.
mn26:15.29.eng: The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it, I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it.

mn26:15.30.pli: Iti yāhaṃ dhammaṃ jānāmi taṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ jānāsi, yaṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ jānāsi tamahaṃ dhammaṃ jānāmi.
mn26:15.30.eng: So the teaching that I know, you know, and the teaching that you know, I know.
mn26:15.30.comm: Almost exactly the same words were spoken by Pokkharasāti to his student Ambaṭṭha (DN 3:1.3.2). This connects Pokkharasāti with Āḷāra Kālāma and Uddaka Rāmaputta, suggesting that the uplifting of a talented student in this way was a regular practice of wise brahmins.

mn26:15.31.pli: Iti yādiso ahaṃ tādiso tuvaṃ, yādiso tuvaṃ tādiso ahaṃ.
mn26:15.31.eng: I am like you and you are like me.

mn26:15.32.pli: Ehi dāni, āvuso, ubhova santā imaṃ gaṇaṃ pariharāmā’ti.
mn26:15.32.eng: Come now, reverend! We should both lead this community together.’
mn26:15.32.comm: This invitation shows his grace and humility.

mn26:15.33.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, āḷāro kālāmo ācariyo me samāno attano antevāsiṃ maṃ samānaṃ attanā samasamaṃ ṭhapesi, uḷārāya ca maṃ pūjāya pūjesi.
mn26:15.33.eng: And that is how my tutor Āḷāra Kālāma placed me, his pupil, on the same position as him, and honored me with high praise.

mn26:15.35.pli: ‘nāyaṃ dhammo nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati, yāvadeva ākiñcaññāyatanūpapattiyā’ti.
mn26:15.35.eng: ‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of nothingness.’
mn26:15.35.comm: It does not fulfill the requirements of the “noble quest”. | Compare the pre-Buddhist meditation practice of Govinda (DN 19:50.9), Mātaṅga (Snp 1.7:27.6), and Maghadeva (MN 83:21.7), which in all cases “leads to rebirth in the Brahmā realm” (brahmalokūpapattiyā). Kaṭha Upaniṣad 1.3.16, concluding the ancient portion of this text, says that the wise man attains glory in the world of divinity (medhāvī brahmaloke mahīyate).

mn26:15.36.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, taṃ dhammaṃ analaṅkaritvā tasmā dhammā nibbijja apakkamiṃ.
mn26:15.36.eng: Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.

mn26:16.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, kiṃ kusalagavesī anuttaraṃ santivarapadaṃ pariyesamāno yena udako rāmaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā udakaṃ rāmaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn26:16.1.eng: I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Uddaka son of Rāma and said to him,
mn26:16.1.comm: Uddaka’s teachings are cited at SN 35.103:1.1 and DN 29:16.13. In the former, his obscure verse assumes the identity of “this” (the impersonal cosmic divinity) with himself, while the latter is a distorted reference to Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4.7. Further, AN 10.29:20.1 implies that he taught the “ultimate purity of the spirit”. While “spirit” (yakkha, Sanskrit yakṣa) is normally a worldly deity, it is identified with the ultimate Brahman at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.4.1 and Kena Upaniṣad 4.1. Uddaka is apparently the “ascetic Rāmaputta” who was revered by the king, criticized by some brahmins, but defended by Todeyya, a leading brahmin of Kosala often mentioned along with Pokkharasāti (AN 4.187:4.2).

mn26:16.2.eng: ‘Reverend, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’
mn26:16.2.comm: In contrast with Āḷāra Kālāma, here the name is omitted.

mn26:16.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, udako rāmaputto maṃ etadavoca:

mn26:16.5.pli: tādiso ayaṃ dhammo yattha viññū puriso nacirasseva sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
mn26:16.5.eng: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’

mn26:16.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, nacirasseva khippameva taṃ dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇiṃ.

mn26:16.7.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, tāvatakeneva oṭṭhapahatamattena lapitalāpanamattena ñāṇavādañca vadāmi theravādañca, ‘jānāmi passāmī’ti ca paṭijānāmi ahañceva aññe ca.
mn26:16.7.eng: As far as lip-recital and verbal repetition went, I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.

mn26:16.9.pli: ‘na kho rāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ kevalaṃ saddhāmattakena sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesi;
mn26:16.9.eng: ‘It is not solely by mere faith that Rāma declared: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”
mn26:16.9.comm: The text shifts from Rāmaputta to just Rāma, while at the same time shifting to the past tense. Uddaka was thus the (spiritual and/or biological) “son of Rāma”. This detail is preserved reliably in the different versions of the text. It seems that Rāmaputta had not personally attained the meditation he was teaching. This would also explain why, just a little below, he invites the Bodhisatta to lead the community rather than to share leadership like Āḷāra Kālāma (MN 36:16.32). SN 35.103:1.6 shows that he did, however, make claims to being spiritually attained.

mn26:16.10.pli: addhā rāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ vihāsī’ti.
mn26:16.10.eng: Surely he meditated knowing and seeing this teaching.’

mn26:16.11.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, yena udako rāmaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā udakaṃ rāmaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn26:16.11.eng: So I approached Uddaka son of Rāma and said to him,

mn26:16.12.pli: ‘kittāvatā no, āvuso, rāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesī’ti?
mn26:16.12.eng: ‘Reverend, to what extent did Rāma say he’d realized this teaching with his own insight?’

mn26:16.13.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, udako rāmaputto nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ pavedesi.
mn26:16.13.eng: When I said this, Uddaka son of Rāma declared the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn26:16.13.comm: In Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12 and 4.5.13, the sage Yājñavalkya says that the true Self is a sheer mass of “consciousness” (vijñāna, Pali viññāṇa), which is “great, endless, infinite reality”. After realizing this, he says, there is no “perception” (saṁjñā, Pali saññā). This passage seems to have sparked the conversation at DN 9:6.4, where the Buddha goes on to speak of meditative training to refine perception. Notably, there he mentions all the jhānas and formless attainments except the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, which is beyond the topic of perception under discussion. This meditative state may be related to the state with “no perception” spoken of by Yājñavalkya. However, it is not possible to literally identify such subtle meditative states on such slender evidence. The point is simply that the contemplative brahmins of the Upaniṣadic tradition of Yājñavalkya did indeed describe their highest state in terms of perception.

mn26:16.15.pli: ‘na kho rāmasseva ahosi saddhā, mayhampatthi saddhā;
mn26:16.15.eng: ‘It’s not just Rāma who had faith,

mn26:16.16.pli: na kho rāmasseva ahosi vīriyaṃ, mayhampatthi vīriyaṃ;

mn26:16.17.pli: na kho rāmasseva ahosi sati, mayhampatthi sati;

mn26:16.18.pli: na kho rāmasseva ahosi samādhi, mayhampatthi samādhi,

mn26:16.19.pli: na kho rāmasseva ahosi paññā, mayhampatthi paññā.
mn26:16.19.eng: and wisdom; I too have these things.

mn26:16.20.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yaṃ dhammaṃ rāmo sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesi, tassa dhammassa sacchikiriyāya padaheyyan’ti.
mn26:16.20.eng: Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Rāma said he had realized with his own insight?’

mn26:16.21.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, nacirasseva khippameva taṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
mn26:16.21.eng: I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.

mn26:16.22.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, yena udako rāmaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā udakaṃ rāmaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn26:16.22.eng: So I approached Uddaka son of Rāma and said to him,

mn26:16.23.pli: ‘Ettāvatā no, āvuso, rāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesī’ti?
mn26:16.23.eng: ‘Reverend, had Rāma realized this teaching with his own insight up to this point, and declared having achieved it?’

mn26:16.24.pli: ‘Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, rāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesī’ti.

mn26:16.25.pli: ‘Ahampi kho, āvuso, ettāvatā imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmī’ti.
mn26:16.25.eng: ‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’

mn26:16.26.eng: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate

mn26:16.27.pli: ye mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ tādisaṃ sabrahmacāriṃ passāma.
mn26:16.27.eng: to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!

mn26:16.28.pli: Iti yaṃ dhammaṃ rāmo sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesi, taṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharasi.
mn26:16.28.eng: So the teaching that Rāma had realized with his own insight, and declared having achieved it, you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it.

mn26:16.29.pli: Yaṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharasi, taṃ dhammaṃ rāmo sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesi.
mn26:16.29.eng: The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it, Rāma had realized with his own insight, and declared having achieved it.

mn26:16.30.pli: Iti yaṃ dhammaṃ rāmo abhiññāsi taṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ jānāsi, yaṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ jānāsi, taṃ dhammaṃ rāmo abhiññāsi.
mn26:16.30.eng: So the teaching that Rāma directly knew, you know, and the teaching you know, Rāma directly knew.

mn26:16.31.pli: Iti yādiso rāmo ahosi tādiso tuvaṃ, yādiso tuvaṃ tādiso rāmo ahosi.
mn26:16.31.eng: Rāma was like you and you are like Rāma.

mn26:16.32.pli: Ehi dāni, āvuso, tuvaṃ imaṃ gaṇaṃ pariharā’ti.
mn26:16.32.eng: Come now, reverend! You should lead this community.’

mn26:16.33.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, udako rāmaputto sabrahmacārī me samāno ācariyaṭṭhāne maṃ ṭhapesi, uḷārāya ca maṃ pūjāya pūjesi.
mn26:16.33.eng: And that is how my spiritual companion Uddaka son of Rāma placed me in the position of a tutor and honored me with high praise.
mn26:16.33.comm: An ācariya is special teacher who has a close, ongoing relationship with a student, signified by the fact that the student of an ācāriya is called an antevāsī, literally “one who lives within” the teacher’s home. This passage confirms that this usage carries over from the Brahmanical tradition, where it is a common term in the same sense. Thus Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.1.2 speaks of “mother, father, and teacher”, while Chāndogya Upaniṣad 2.23.1 enjoins a student to “live with the teacher until death”, and at 4.9.1 ff. we see the journey of a student to their teacher’s house, where he is looked after by the teacher and his wife. The same sense prevails throughout the suttas and Vinaya, so I translate as “tutor” to identify a close personal teacher.

mn26:16.35.pli: ‘nāyaṃ dhammo nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati, yāvadeva nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpapattiyā’ti.
mn26:16.35.eng: ‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

mn26:16.36.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, taṃ dhammaṃ analaṅkaritvā tasmā dhammā nibbijja apakkamiṃ.
mn26:16.36.eng: Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.

mn26:17.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, kiṃ kusalagavesī anuttaraṃ santivarapadaṃ pariyesamāno magadhesu anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena uruvelā senānigamo tadavasariṃ.
mn26:17.1.eng: I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. Traveling stage by stage in the Magadhan lands, I arrived at the town of Senā in Uruvelā.
mn26:17.1.comm: In modern times this is the pilgrimage site Bodhgaya in the Gaya district of Bihar. It lies by a wide river that is dry in summer but abundant in the rains. Today it is named Līlajan and in Pali Nerañjarā, although that name is not mentioned in this passage. Uruvelā, which aptly means “Broadbanks”, was a locality centered around the market town of Senānigama (“Marshalltown”). There was also a sizable hermitage nearby with matted-hair Brahmanical ascetics (jaṭilā) who ritually bathed in the water (Kd 1:20.15.1). After teaching the five monks in Varanasi, the Buddha returned here to teach them, but there is no record of him visiting subsequently.

mn26:17.2.pli: Tatthaddasaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ bhūmibhāgaṃ, pāsādikañca vanasaṇḍaṃ, nadiñca sandantiṃ setakaṃ supatitthaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ, samantā ca gocaragāmaṃ.
mn26:17.2.eng: There I saw a delightful park, a lovely grove with a flowing river that was clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby was a village to resort to for alms.
mn26:17.2.comm: The Buddha’s rejection of sensual pleasures does not preclude his appreciation of nature’s beauty. | The local alms villages in Uruvelā are named in Mahāvastu 2.207 as Praskandaka, Balākalpa, Ujjaṁgala, and Jaṁgala.

mn26:17.4.pli: ‘ramaṇīyo vata bho bhūmibhāgo, pāsādiko ca vanasaṇḍo, nadī ca sandati setakā supatitthā ramaṇīyā, samantā ca gocaragāmo.
mn26:17.4.eng: ‘This park is truly delightful, a lovely grove with a flowing river that’s clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby there’s a village to resort to for alms.

mn26:17.5.eng: This is good enough for striving for a gentleman wanting to strive.’
mn26:17.5.comm: Padhāna means to “strive”. It is frequently used in the sense of applying oneself to meditation, but here it leads into the painful “striving” of fervent austerity (MN 36:20.7).

mn26:17.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, tattheva nisīdiṃ—
mn26:17.6.eng: So I sat down right there, thinking,

mn26:18.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, attanā jātidhammo samāno jātidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajātaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesamāno ajātaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ ajjhagamaṃ, attanā jarādhammo samāno jarādhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajaraṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesamāno ajaraṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ ajjhagamaṃ, attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā abyādhiṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesamāno abyādhiṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ ajjhagamaṃ, attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā amataṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ ajjhagamaṃ, attanā sokadhammo samāno sokadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā asokaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ ajjhagamaṃ, attanā saṅkilesadhammo samāno saṅkilesadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā asaṅkiliṭṭhaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesamāno asaṅkiliṭṭhaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ ajjhagamaṃ.
mn26:18.1.eng: And so, being myself liable to be reborn, understanding the drawbacks in being liable to be reborn, I sought that which is free of rebirth, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment—and I found it. Being myself liable to grow old, fall sick, die, sorrow, and become corrupted, understanding the drawbacks in these things, I sought that which is free of old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and corruption, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment—and I found it.
mn26:18.1.comm: While this skips directly from his arrival in Uruvelā to his awakening, other texts describe his practice of fervent austerities here, which must have taken a considerable time (MN 36:16.7, MN 85:15.1). See note on MN 26:18.1.

mn26:18.2.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

mn26:18.3.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’ti.
mn26:18.3.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’
mn26:18.3.comm: This is the realization of arahantship. Elsewhere the Buddha goes into more detail as to the process of meditation that led to this point.

mn26:19.2.pli: ‘adhigato kho myāyaṃ dhammo gambhīro duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo.
mn26:19.2.eng: ‘This principle I have discovered is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.
mn26:19.2.comm: A similar account is told of Gotama Buddha at SN 6.1:1.4, MN 85:43.2, and Kd 1:5.2.2, and of Vipassī at DN 14:3.1.4.

mn26:19.3.pli: Ālayarāmā kho panāyaṃ pajā ālayaratā ālayasammuditā.
mn26:19.3.eng: But people like clinging, they love it and enjoy it.

mn26:19.4.pli: Ālayarāmāya kho pana pajāya ālayaratāya ālayasammuditāya duddasaṃ idaṃ ṭhānaṃ yadidaṃ—idappaccayatā paṭiccasamuppādo.
mn26:19.4.eng: It’s hard for them to see this topic; that is, specific conditionality, dependent origination.
mn26:19.4.comm: The Buddha identifies the two most difficult topics in his philosophy: dependent origination and Nibbana.

mn26:19.5.pli: Idampi kho ṭhānaṃ duddasaṃ yadidaṃ—sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.
mn26:19.5.eng: It’s also hard for them to see this topic; that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.

mn26:19.6.pli: Ahañceva kho pana dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ, pare ca me na ājāneyyuṃ, so mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā’ti.
mn26:19.6.eng: And if I were to teach this principle, others might not understand me, which would be wearying and troublesome for me.’
mn26:19.6.comm: Up to this point, the Bodhisatta has been solely concerned with finding the answer to his quest, and only now does he think of sharing it with others. The idea that he had made an aspiration for Buddhahood in the long ago past out of a desire to help all sentient beings is not supported in early texts.

mn26:19.7.pli: Apissu maṃ, bhikkhave, imā anacchariyā gāthāyo paṭibhaṃsu pubbe assutapubbā:
mn26:19.7.eng: And then these verses, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me:

mn26:19.9.eng: enough with trying to explain it!

mn26:19.10.eng: Those mired in greed and hate

mn26:19.12.eng: It goes against the stream, subtle,

mn26:19.14.eng: Those besotted by greed cannot see,

mn26:19.15.eng: for they’re shrouded in a mass of darkness.’

mn26:19.16.pli: Itiha me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato appossukkatāya cittaṃ namati, no dhammadesanāya.
mn26:19.16.eng: So, as I reflected like this, my mind inclined to remaining passive, not to teaching the Dhamma.
mn26:19.16.comm: Had he followed this inclination he would have been a paccekabuddha, a Buddha “awakened for himself”.

mn26:20.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, brahmuno sahampatissa mama cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya etadahosi:
mn26:20.1.eng: Then the divinity Sahampati, knowing my train of thought, thought,
mn26:20.1.comm: While Sahampati features prominently in the suttas, no deity of that name is found in early Brahmanical texts. He seems, however, to be the Buddhist version of Brahmā Svayambhū, the “Self-born Divinity”, to whom Yājñavalkya traces the authority of his teaching lineage (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.6.3, 4.5.3, 6.5.4). Yājñavalkya identifies this “self-born” with the sun (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.9.3.16; see also Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā 4.6.6) and with Prajāpati (13.5.3.1). Explaining the origin of the soma rite of the “All-Sacrifice”, he says that Brahmā Svayambhū, while performing fervent austerities, decided to offer his self to all creatures and all creatures to his self, thus establishing lordship (adhipatya) over all creatures (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 13.7.1.1). The root pati (“lord”) here establishes a linguistic link with sahampati. Further, in the earliest use of svayambhū at Rig Veda 10.83.4, the “self-born” deity Manyu “prevails” (sahuriḥ sahāvān) in battle. Thus we can identify Sahampati, the “Lord Who Prevails”, with the highest divinity recognized by Yājñavalkya, who originated as victor in battle, whose physical manifestation is the sun, whose spiritual function is to imbue all creatures with divinity, and who serves as the ultimate source of authority. Meanwhile, the epithet sayambhū was taken for the Buddha (Kd 11:35.1.37).

mn26:20.2.pli: ‘nassati vata bho loko, vinassati vata bho loko, yatra hi nāma tathāgatassa arahato sammāsambuddhassa appossukkatāya cittaṃ namati, no dhammadesanāyā’ti.
mn26:20.2.eng: ‘Oh lord! The world will be lost, the world will perish! For the mind of the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, inclines to remaining passive, not to teaching the Dhamma.’
mn26:20.2.comm: Having surpassed the greatest of the Brahmanical contemplatives, the Buddha’s achievement is recognized by the chief Brahmanical divinity.

mn26:20.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, brahmā sahampati—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito mama purato pāturahosi.
mn26:20.3.eng: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of me.

mn26:20.4.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, brahmā sahampati ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yenāhaṃ tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā maṃ etadavoca:
mn26:20.4.eng: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward me, and said,

mn26:20.5.pli: ‘desetu, bhante, bhagavā dhammaṃ, desetu sugato dhammaṃ.
mn26:20.5.eng: ‘Sir, let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach the Dhamma!

mn26:20.6.pli: Santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti.
mn26:20.6.eng: There are beings with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching.

mn26:20.7.eng: There will be those who understand the teaching!’
mn26:20.7.comm: Sahampati is the one who recognizes the potential in all beings, since it was he who imbued them with divinity. He did this to ensure dominance, but now his motive has transformed into compassion.

mn26:20.8.eng: That’s what the divinity Sahampati said.

mn26:20.9.eng: Then he went on to say:

mn26:20.10.eng: ‘Among the Magadhans there appeared in the past

mn26:20.11.eng: an impure teaching thought up by the stained.
mn26:20.11.comm: The “impure teaching” was, according to the commentary, that of the six ascetic teachers, who are regularly associated with Magadha (eg. SN 2.30, Snp 3.6, DN 2). Less likely it refers to Brahmanical teachers like Āḷāra Kālāma and Uddaka Rāmaputta, who are more closely associated with Kosala and whose system is regarded as passed down rather than “thought up”.

mn26:20.12.eng: Fling open the door to freedom from death!
mn26:20.12.comm: “Freedom from death” (amata, Sanskrit amṛta) is yet another Brahmanical term transformed by the Buddha. Its Vedic meaning was “immortality”, and hence the “ambrosia” of soma through which immortality was gained. For the Buddha, as seen in the “noble quest” itself, it was the freedom from the cycles of birth, aging, and death.

mn26:20.13.eng: Let them hear the teaching <j>the immaculate one discovered.

mn26:20.14.eng: Standing high on a rocky mountain,

mn26:20.15.eng: you can see the people all around.

mn26:20.16.eng: In just the same way, All-seer, so intelligent,

mn26:20.17.eng: having ascended the Temple of Truth,

mn26:20.18.eng: rid of sorrow, look upon the people

mn26:20.19.eng: swamped with sorrow, overcome by rebirth and old age.

mn26:20.20.eng: Rise, hero! Victor in battle, caravan leader,
mn26:20.20.comm: Here we see a verbal echo of Sahampati’s martial origins.

mn26:20.21.eng: wander the world cleared of debt.
mn26:20.21.comm: A “caravan leader” (satthavāha) guides their flock through treacherous deserts and wastelands, as illustrated at DN 23:23.3. | Anaṇa (“debtless”) is a technical term in the Vedic system. According to Manu 6.35–7, a renunciate must first pay off three debts: study of Vedas, begetting a son, and offering of sacrifices. One who goes forth with these debts unpaid is headed for a downfall. The Buddha has indeed paid off all these debts: he studied the Vedas under his former teachers (MN 26:15.6); he has a son Rāhula; and his path is regarded as the highest form of sacrifice (DN 5:24.1). But in Buddhism the concept is reinterpreted as meaning one has let go of all defilements, becoming a “perfected”, literally “worthy” one, after which one can eat almsfood free of debt (MN 124:38.1, SN 16.11:13.2).

mn26:20.22.eng: Let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma!

mn26:20.23.eng: There will be those who understand!’

mn26:21.1.pli: Atha kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmuno ca ajjhesanaṃ viditvā sattesu ca kāruññataṃ paṭicca buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokesiṃ.
mn26:21.1.eng: Then, understanding the Divinity’s invitation, I surveyed the world with the eye of a Buddha, because of my compassion for sentient beings.

mn26:21.2.pli: Addasaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokento satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe, tikkhindriye mudindriye, svākāre dvākāre, suviññāpaye duviññāpaye, appekacce paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante, appekacce na paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante.
mn26:21.2.eng: And I saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes; with keen faculties and with weak faculties, with good qualities and with bad qualities, easy to teach and hard to teach. And some of them lived seeing the danger in the fault to do with the next world, while others did not.
mn26:21.2.comm: Here we see the sense of indriya as “spiritual potential”. Originally it was the state of excited energy produced by soma that allowed Indra to manifest his full power and overcome his foes. It implicitly links back to the five spiritual qualities that the Buddha attributed to his teachers, which he later formalized as “faculties”. Here as there, the idea creates a connection between beings, a recognition of shared qualities that, when properly nurtured, can mature into awakening.

mn26:21.3.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma uppaliniyaṃ vā paduminiyaṃ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṃ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni antonimuggaposīni, appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni samodakaṃ ṭhitāni, appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakaṃ accuggamma ṭhitāni anupalittāni udakena;
mn26:21.3.eng: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. Some of them sprout and grow in the water reaching the water’s surface. And some of them sprout and grow in the water but rise up above the water and stand with no water clinging to them.

mn26:21.4.pli: evameva kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokento addasaṃ satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe, tikkhindriye mudindriye, svākāre dvākāre, suviññāpaye duviññāpaye, appekacce paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante, appekacce na paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante.
mn26:21.4.eng: In the same way, I saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes.

mn26:21.5.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmānaṃ sahampatiṃ gāthāya paccabhāsiṃ:
mn26:21.5.eng: Then I replied in verse to the divinity Sahampati:

mn26:21.6.eng: ‘Flung open are the doors to freedom from death!

mn26:21.7.eng: Let those with ears to hear commit to faith.
mn26:21.7.comm: Pamuñcantu saddhaṁ has long troubled translators, as the basic sense of pamuñcantu is “release”. Sanskrit variants include pramodantu (“celebrate”) or praṇudantu kāṅkṣāḥ (“dispel doubts”). I think it is a poetic variant of adhimuñcantu, to “decide” or “commit” to faith. Pali commonly uses synonymous verbs to reinforce the sense of the noun. In Snp 5.19, muttasaddho, pamuñcassu saddhaṁ, and adhimuttacittaṁ are all used in this sense.

mn26:21.8.eng: Thinking it would be troublesome, Divinity, <j>I did not teach

mn26:21.9.eng: the sophisticated, sublime Dhamma among mankind.’

mn26:21.10.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, brahmā sahampati ‘katāvakāso khomhi bhagavatā dhammadesanāyā’ti maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
mn26:21.10.eng: Then the divinity Sahampati, knowing that his request for me to teach the Dhamma had been granted, bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right, before vanishing right there.

mn26:22.2.pli: ‘kassa nu kho ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ;
mn26:22.2.eng: ‘Who should I teach first of all?

mn26:22.3.eng: Who will quickly understand this teaching?’

mn26:22.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āḷāro kālāmo paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī dīgharattaṃ apparajakkhajātiko.
mn26:22.5.eng: ‘That Āḷāra Kālāma is astute, competent, clever, and has long had little dust in his eyes.

mn26:22.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ āḷārassa kālāmassa paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ.
mn26:22.6.eng: Why don’t I teach him first of all?

mn26:22.8.pli: Atha kho maṃ, bhikkhave, devatā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
mn26:22.8.eng: But a deity came to me and said,

mn26:22.9.eng: ‘Sir, Āḷāra Kālāma passed away seven days ago.’

mn26:22.10.eng: And knowledge and vision arose in me,

mn26:22.11.eng: ‘Āḷāra Kālāma passed away seven days ago.’

mn26:22.13.eng: ‘This is a great loss for Āḷāra Kālāma.

mn26:22.14.pli: Sace hi so imaṃ dhammaṃ suṇeyya, khippameva ājāneyyā’ti.
mn26:22.14.eng: If he had heard the teaching, he would have understood it quickly.’

mn26:23.2.pli: ‘kassa nu kho ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ;
mn26:23.2.eng: ‘Who should I teach first of all?

mn26:23.3.eng: Who will quickly understand this teaching?’

mn26:23.5.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho udako rāmaputto paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī dīgharattaṃ apparajakkhajātiko.
mn26:23.5.eng: ‘That Uddaka son of Rāma is astute, competent, clever, and has long had little dust in his eyes.

mn26:23.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ udakassa rāmaputtassa paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ.
mn26:23.6.eng: Why don’t I teach him first of all?

mn26:23.8.pli: Atha kho maṃ, bhikkhave, devatā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
mn26:23.8.eng: But a deity came to me and said,

mn26:23.9.eng: ‘Sir, Uddaka son of Rāma passed away just last night.’

mn26:23.10.eng: And knowledge and vision arose in me,

mn26:23.11.eng: ‘Uddaka son of Rāma passed away just last night.’

mn26:23.13.eng: ‘This is a great loss for Uddaka.

mn26:23.14.pli: Sace hi so imaṃ dhammaṃ suṇeyya, khippameva ājāneyyā’ti.
mn26:23.14.eng: If he had heard the teaching, he would have understood it quickly.’
mn26:23.14.comm: While this passage is clearly heightened for dramatic effect, it is not surprising that they have passed away. It has been several years since he studied with these teachers, and they were probably elderly at the time, as perhaps hinted in their eagerness to appoint Siddhattha as heirs.

mn26:24.2.pli: ‘kassa nu kho ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ;
mn26:24.2.eng: ‘Who should I teach first of all?

mn26:24.3.eng: Who will quickly understand this teaching?’

mn26:24.5.pli: ‘bahukārā kho me pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū, ye maṃ padhānapahitattaṃ upaṭṭhahiṃsu.
mn26:24.5.eng: ‘The group of five mendicants were very helpful to me. They looked after me during my time of resolute striving.
mn26:24.5.comm: The five mendicants appear abruptly here and the reason for their behavior is only clear in light of the fuller accounts (MN 36:33.4, MN 85:33.4, MN 100:30.5). The Buddha’s praise for them is more muted than for the Brahmanical teachers, showing how he valued advanced meditation over austerities. | Note that he calls them “mendicants”, a term typically reserved for Buddhist renunciates. For a similar usage, see MN 140:3.4.

mn26:24.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ pañcavaggiyānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyan’ti.
mn26:24.6.eng: Why don’t I teach them first of all?’

mn26:24.8.pli: ‘kahaṃ nu kho etarahi pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū viharantī’ti?
mn26:24.8.eng: ‘Where are the group of five mendicants staying these days?’

mn26:24.9.pli: Addasaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena pañcavaggiye bhikkhū bārāṇasiyaṃ viharante isipatane migadāye.
mn26:24.9.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman I saw that the group of five mendicants were staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.

mn26:24.10.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, uruvelāyaṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena bārāṇasī tena cārikaṃ pakkamiṃ.
mn26:24.10.eng: So, when I had stayed in Uruvelā as long as I pleased, I set out for Varanasi.
mn26:24.10.comm: Several suttas relate further details in this period (eg. SN 47.43, Ud 1.3–4, etc.)

mn26:25.1.pli: Addasā kho maṃ, bhikkhave, upako ājīvako antarā ca gayaṃ antarā ca bodhiṃ addhānamaggappaṭipannaṃ.
mn26:25.1.eng: While I was traveling along the road between Gayā and Bodhgaya, the Ājīvaka ascetic Upaka saw me
mn26:25.1.comm: For the Ājīvakas, see MN 5:31.7 and DN 2:20.2. Upaka is met only here; his name means “nearly there”. | The place of awakening is referred to as bodhi. These places are about twenty kilometers apart.

mn26:25.3.pli: ‘vippasannāni kho te, āvuso, indriyāni, parisuddho chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto.
mn26:25.3.eng: ‘Reverend, your faculties are so very clear, and your complexion is pure and bright.
mn26:25.3.comm: Here “faculties” refers to visible features such as bright eyes. Compare Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.14.2, where a students face is seen as bright and glowing due to their recent insights.

mn26:25.4.pli: Kaṃsi tvaṃ, āvuso, uddissa pabbajito, ko vā te satthā, kassa vā tvaṃ dhammaṃ rocesī’ti?
mn26:25.4.eng: In whose name have you gone forth, reverend? Who is your Teacher? Whose teaching do you believe in?’

mn26:25.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhikkhave, upakaṃ ājīvakaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsiṃ:
mn26:25.5.eng: I replied to Upaka in verse:

mn26:25.6.eng: ‘I am the champion, the knower of all,

mn26:25.7.eng: unsullied in the midst of all things.

mn26:25.8.eng: I’ve given up all, freed through the ending of craving.

mn26:25.9.eng: Since I know for myself, whose follower should I be?

mn26:25.12.eng: In the world with its gods,

mn26:25.14.eng: For in this world, I am the perfected one;

mn26:25.18.eng: I am going to the city of Kāsi

mn26:25.19.eng: to roll forth the Wheel of Dhamma.

mn26:25.20.eng: In this world that is so blind,

mn26:25.21.eng: I’ll beat the drum of freedom from death!’
mn26:25.21.comm: Āhañchaṁ is first person future singular of āhanati, “one beats”.

mn26:25.22.pli: ‘Yathā kho tvaṃ, āvuso, paṭijānāsi, arahasi anantajino’ti.
mn26:25.22.eng: ‘According to what you claim, reverend, you ought to be the Infinite Victor.’
mn26:25.22.comm: “Infinite Victor” (anantajina) is unknown elsewhere and may be an Ājīvaka term. It relates to the epithet jina of the teacher Mahāvīra, after which his followers the Jains were named. Mahāvīra and the Ājīvaka founder Gosāla practiced together for six years, so it comes as no surprise that they shared terminology.

mn26:25.23.eng: ‘The victors are those who, like me,

mn26:25.24.eng: have reached the ending of defilements.

mn26:25.25.eng: I have conquered bad qualities, Upaka—

mn26:25.27.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, upako ājīvako ‘hupeyyapāvuso’ti vatvā sīsaṃ okampetvā ummaggaṃ gahetvā pakkāmi.
mn26:25.27.eng: When I had spoken, Upaka said: ‘If you say so, reverend.’ Shaking his head, he took a wrong turn and left.

mn26:26.1.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena bārāṇasī isipatanaṃ migadāyo yena pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkamiṃ.
mn26:26.1.eng: Traveling stage by stage, I arrived at Varanasi, and went to see the group of five mendicants in the deer park at Isipatana.

mn26:26.2.pli: Addasaṃsu kho maṃ, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū dūrato āgacchantaṃ.
mn26:26.2.eng: The group of five mendicants saw me coming off in the distance

mn26:26.3.comm: For “they stopped each other” (aññamaññaṁ saṇṭhapesuṁ), see AN 10.93:2.4.

mn26:26.4.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho, āvuso, samaṇo gotamo āgacchati bāhulliko padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya.
mn26:26.4.eng: ‘Here comes the ascetic Gotama. He’s so indulgent; he strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.

mn26:26.5.pli: So neva abhivādetabbo, na paccuṭṭhātabbo; nāssa pattacīvaraṃ paṭiggahetabbaṃ.
mn26:26.5.eng: We shouldn’t bow to him or rise for him or receive his bowl and robe.

mn26:26.6.pli: Api ca kho āsanaṃ ṭhapetabbaṃ, sace ākaṅkhissati nisīdissatī’ti.
mn26:26.6.eng: But we can set out a seat; he can sit if he likes.’

mn26:26.7.pli: Yathā yathā kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, upasaṅkamiṃ tathā tathā pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū nāsakkhiṃsu sakāya katikāya saṇṭhātuṃ.
mn26:26.7.eng: Yet as I drew closer, the group of five mendicants were unable to stop themselves per their own agreement.

mn26:26.8.pli: Appekacce maṃ paccuggantvā pattacīvaraṃ paṭiggahesuṃ, appekacce āsanaṃ paññapesuṃ, appekacce pādodakaṃ upaṭṭhapesuṃ.
mn26:26.8.eng: Some came out to greet me and receive my bowl and robe, some spread out a seat, while others set out water for washing my feet.

mn26:26.9.pli: Api ca kho maṃ nāmena ca āvusovādena ca samudācaranti.
mn26:26.9.eng: But they still addressed me by name and as ‘reverend’.
mn26:26.9.comm: These ways of address are suitable for a senior speaking to a junior (DN 16:6.2.2).

mn26:27.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavocaṃ:

mn26:27.2.pli: ‘mā, bhikkhave, tathāgataṃ nāmena ca āvusovādena ca samudācaratha.
mn26:27.2.eng: ‘Mendicants, don’t address me by name and as “reverend”.

mn26:27.3.eng: The Realized One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.

mn26:27.4.pli: Odahatha, bhikkhave, sotaṃ, amatamadhigataṃ, ahamanusāsāmi, ahaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.
mn26:27.4.eng: Listen up, mendicants: I have achieved freedom from death! I shall instruct you, I will teach you the Dhamma.

mn26:27.5.pli: Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamānā nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti.
mn26:27.5.eng: By practicing as instructed you will soon realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. You will live having achieved with your own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

mn26:27.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū maṃ etadavocuṃ:

mn26:27.7.pli: ‘tāyapi kho tvaṃ, āvuso gotama, iriyāya tāya paṭipadāya tāya dukkarakārikāya nājjhagamā uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṃ, kiṃ pana tvaṃ etarahi bāhulliko padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya adhigamissasi uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesan’ti?
mn26:27.7.eng: ‘Reverend Gotama, even by that conduct, that practice, that grueling work you did not achieve any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones. How could you have achieved such a state now that you’ve become indulgent, strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence?’
mn26:27.7.comm: Where “that practice” appears in MN 12:56.1 and MN 85:51.7, it refers to the austere practices that have just been described. Taken together with the abrupt skip at MN 26:18.1 above, and the equally abrupt mention of the five mendicants at MN 26:24.5, it seems likely the passage on the austerities has been removed in order to focus on the Brahmanical context.

mn26:27.8.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavocaṃ:

mn26:27.9.pli: ‘na, bhikkhave, tathāgato bāhulliko, na padhānavibbhanto, na āvatto bāhullāya.
mn26:27.9.eng: ‘The Realized One has not become indulgent, strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.

mn26:27.10.eng: The Realized One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.

mn26:27.11.pli: Odahatha, bhikkhave, sotaṃ, amatamadhigataṃ, ahamanusāsāmi, ahaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.
mn26:27.11.eng: Listen up, mendicants: I have achieved freedom from death! I shall instruct you, I will teach you the Dhamma.

mn26:27.12.pli: Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamānā nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti.
mn26:27.12.eng: By practicing as instructed you will soon realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life.’

mn26:27.13.pli: Dutiyampi kho, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū maṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn26:27.13.eng: But for a second time they said to me,

mn26:27.14.pli: ‘tāyapi kho tvaṃ, āvuso gotama, iriyāya tāya paṭipadāya tāya dukkarakārikāya nājjhagamā uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṃ, kiṃ pana tvaṃ etarahi bāhulliko padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya adhigamissasi uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesan’ti?

mn26:27.15.pli: Dutiyampi kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavocaṃ:
mn26:27.15.eng: So for a second time I said to them,

mn26:27.16.eng: ‘The Realized One has not become indulgent …’

mn26:27.18.pli: Tatiyampi kho, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū maṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn26:27.18.eng: But for a third time they said to me,

mn26:27.19.pli: ‘tāyapi kho tvaṃ, āvuso gotama, iriyāya tāya paṭipadāya tāya dukkarakārikāya nājjhagamā uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṃ, kiṃ pana tvaṃ etarahi bāhulliko padhānavibbhanto āvatto bāhullāya adhigamissasi uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesan’ti?
mn26:27.19.eng: ‘Reverend Gotama, even by that conduct, that practice, that grueling work you did not achieve any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones. How could you have achieved such a state now that you’ve become indulgent, strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence?’

mn26:28.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiye bhikkhū etadavocaṃ:

mn26:28.2.pli: ‘abhijānātha me no tumhe, bhikkhave, ito pubbe evarūpaṃ pabhāvitametan’ti?
mn26:28.2.eng: ‘Mendicants, have you ever known me to speak like this before?’

mn26:28.3.comm: Here they adopt the more respectful term of address bhante (“sir”).

mn26:28.4.eng: ‘The Realized One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.

mn26:28.5.pli: Odahatha, bhikkhave, sotaṃ, amatamadhigataṃ, ahamanusāsāmi, ahaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.
mn26:28.5.eng: Listen up, mendicants: I have achieved freedom from death! I shall instruct you, I will teach you the Dhamma.

mn26:28.6.pli: Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ tathā paṭipajjamānā nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathā’ti.
mn26:28.6.eng: By practicing as instructed you will soon realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. You will live having achieved with your own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

mn26:29.1.pli: Asakkhiṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiye bhikkhū saññāpetuṃ.
mn26:29.1.eng: I was able to persuade the group of five mendicants.
mn26:29.1.comm: Again the narrative skips. Here the Buddha taught the “Rolling Forth of the Wheel of the Dhamma” (SN 56.11). The full sequence of events is related in Kd 1:6.16.9.

mn26:29.2.pli: Dvepi sudaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū ovadāmi, tayo bhikkhū piṇḍāya caranti.
mn26:29.2.eng: Then sometimes I advised two mendicants, while the other three went for alms.

mn26:29.3.pli: Yaṃ tayo bhikkhū piṇḍāya caritvā āharanti tena chabbaggiyā yāpema.
mn26:29.3.eng: Then those three would feed all six of us with what they brought back.

mn26:29.4.pli: Tayopi sudaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū ovadāmi, dve bhikkhū piṇḍāya caranti.
mn26:29.4.eng: Sometimes I advised three mendicants, while the other two went for alms.

mn26:29.5.pli: Yaṃ dve bhikkhū piṇḍāya caritvā āharanti tena chabbaggiyā yāpema.
mn26:29.5.eng: Then those two would feed all six of us with what they brought back.

mn26:30.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū mayā evaṃ ovadiyamānā evaṃ anusāsiyamānā attanā jātidhammā samānā jātidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajātaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesamānā ajātaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ ajjhagamaṃsu, attanā jarādhammā samānā jarādhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajaraṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesamānā ajaraṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ ajjhagamaṃsu, attanā byādhidhammā samānā …pe… attanā maraṇadhammā samānā … attanā sokadhammā samānā … attanā saṅkilesadhammā samānā saṅkilesadhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā asaṅkiliṭṭhaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesamānā asaṅkiliṭṭhaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ ajjhagamaṃsu.
mn26:30.1.eng: As the group of five mendicants were being advised and instructed by me like this, being themselves liable to be reborn, understanding the drawbacks in being liable to be reborn, they sought that which is free of rebirth, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment—and they found it. Being themselves liable to grow old, fall sick, die, sorrow, and become corrupted, understanding the drawbacks in these things, they sought that which is free of old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and corruption, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment—and they found it.

mn26:30.2.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in them:

mn26:30.3.pli: ‘akuppā no vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’ti.
mn26:30.3.eng: ‘Our freedom is unshakable; this is our last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’
mn26:30.3.comm: This occurred with the teaching of the “Discourse on the Characteristic of Not Self” (SN 22.59).

mn26:31.1.eng: Mendicants, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
mn26:31.1.comm: The Buddha rather abruptly returns to a direct teaching for the mendicants in Rammaka’s hermitage. The topic harks back to the simile of the sappy log, absent from here, but which in MN 36:17.1 is introduced as the Bodhisatta undertook striving at Uruvelā.

mn26:31.3.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
mn26:31.3.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn26:31.7.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
mn26:31.7.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

mn26:31.8.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

mn26:32.1.pli: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ime pañca kāmaguṇe gathitā mucchitā ajjhopannā anādīnavadassāvino anissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjanti, te evamassu veditabbā:
mn26:32.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape. You should understand that they
mn26:32.1.comm: The Pali word paribhuñjati means “to have something satisfying” as well as “to take pleasure in”, much like the English word “enjoys”.

mn26:32.2.eng: have met with calamity and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

mn26:32.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āraññako mago baddho pāsarāsiṃ adhisayeyya.
mn26:32.3.eng: Suppose a deer in the wilderness was lying caught on a pile of snares.
mn26:32.3.comm: This image and the teaching that follows links this sutta with the previous.

mn26:32.5.eng: has met with calamity and disaster, and the hunter can do with them what he wants.

mn26:32.6.pli: Āgacchante ca pana ludde yena kāmaṃ na pakkamissatī’ti.
mn26:32.6.eng: And when the hunter comes, it cannot flee where it wants.

mn26:32.7.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ime pañca kāmaguṇe gathitā mucchitā ajjhopannā anādīnavadassāvino anissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjanti, te evamassu veditabbā:
mn26:32.7.eng: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape. You should understand that they

mn26:32.8.eng: have met with calamity and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.

mn26:33.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ime pañca kāmaguṇe agathitā amucchitā anajjhopannā ādīnavadassāvino nissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjanti, te evamassu veditabbā:
mn26:33.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation without being tied, infatuated, or attached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape. You should understand that they

mn26:33.2.pli: ‘na anayamāpannā na byasanamāpannā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā pāpimato’.
mn26:33.2.eng: haven’t met with calamity and disaster, and the Wicked One cannot do what he wants with them.

mn26:33.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āraññako mago abaddho pāsarāsiṃ adhisayeyya.
mn26:33.3.eng: Suppose a deer in the wilderness was lying on a pile of snares without being caught.

mn26:33.5.pli: ‘na anayamāpanno na byasanamāpanno na yathākāmakaraṇīyo luddassa.
mn26:33.5.eng: hasn’t met with calamity and disaster, and the hunter cannot do what he wants with them.

mn26:33.6.pli: Āgacchante ca pana ludde yena kāmaṃ pakkamissatī’ti.
mn26:33.6.eng: And when the hunter comes, it can flee where it wants.

mn26:33.7.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ime pañca kāmaguṇe agathitā amucchitā anajjhopannā ādīnavadassāvino nissaraṇapaññā paribhuñjanti, te evamassu veditabbā:
mn26:33.7.eng: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation without being tied, infatuated, or attached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape. You should understand that they

mn26:33.8.pli: ‘na anayamāpannā na byasanamāpannā na yathākāmakaraṇīyā pāpimato’.
mn26:33.8.eng: haven’t met with calamity and disaster, and the Wicked One cannot do what he wants with them.

mn26:34.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āraññako mago araññe pavane caramāno vissattho gacchati, vissattho tiṭṭhati, vissattho nisīdati, vissattho seyyaṃ kappeti.
